title: PCAtest: Statistical significance of PCA
text: PCA meaningful applied significant correlation structure among least variables dataset. Due sampling variance alone, possible level random correlation structure occur data. Therefore, necessary evaluate observed correlation structure higher expected due chance alone. PCAtest uses pair statistics, Psi Phi, based eigenvalues (roots) PCA evaluate significance comparing observed values null distributions. expected values Psi Phi calculated random permutations observations within variables, effectively removes correlation structure among variables. observed statistics larger expected null distributions, PCA meaningless used. null hypothesis non-significant PCA rejected, PCAtest calculates observed eigenvalues builds null distributions select number significant PCs. addition, PCAtest also calculates two statistics: index loadings correlations PC variables, test contribution observed variables significant PC.

title: PCAtest: Statistical significance of PCA
text: PCAtest reject null hypothesis non-significant PCA, correlation structure among variables. can generate analyze PCAtest set uncorrelated variables:
code: library(PCAtest) library(MASS) mu <- rep(0,5) Sigma <- matrix(c(rep(c(1,0,0,0,0,0),4),1),5) ex0 <- mvrnorm(100, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma ) result<-PCAtest(ex0, 100, 100, 0.05, indload=FALSE, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 5 variables, 100 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 0.2505, Max null Psi = 0.4141, Min null Psi = 0.0363, p-value = 0.15 #> Empirical Phi = 0.1119, Max null Phi = 0.1439, Min null Phi = 0.0426, p-value = 0.15 #>  #> PCA is not significant!

what: Selecting the number of significant PCs
title: PCAtest: Statistical significance of PCA
text: PCA significant, PCAtest uses random permutations test PC axes significant based random permutation calculation percentage total variation explained PC axis. can use published dataset Wong & Carmona (2021, https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.13568) consisting seven morphological variables measured 29 ant species:
code: data("ants") result<-PCAtest(ants, 100, 100, 0.05, indload=FALSE, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 7 variables, 29 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 10.9186, Max null Psi = 2.4335, Min null Psi = 0.7399, p-value = 0 #> Empirical Phi = 0.5099, Max null Phi = 0.2407, Min null Phi = 0.1327, p-value = 0 #>  #> Empirical eigenvalue #1 = 3.84712, Max null eigenvalue = 2.20197, p-value = 0 #> Empirical eigenvalue #2 = 1.52017, Max null eigenvalue = 1.66424, p-value = 0.18 #> Empirical eigenvalue #3 = 0.70634, Max null eigenvalue = 1.38726, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #4 = 0.41356, Max null eigenvalue = 1.16479, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #5 = 0.34001, Max null eigenvalue = 0.92378, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #6 = 0.14515, Max null eigenvalue = 0.76744, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #7 = 0.02765, Max null eigenvalue = 0.53648, p-value = 1 #>  #> PC 1 is significant and accounts for 55% (95%-CI:40-63.6) of the total variation

what: Testing which variables have significant loadings
title: PCAtest: Statistical significance of PCA
text: addition selecting number significant PC axes, usually interested finding variables significant loadings significant PC axis. PCAtest runs random permutations plots index loadings significant PCs:
code: data("ants") result<-PCAtest(ants, 100, 100, 0.05, indload=TRUE, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 7 variables, 29 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 10.9186, Max null Psi = 2.4714, Min null Psi = 0.5735, p-value = 0 #> Empirical Phi = 0.5099, Max null Phi = 0.2426, Min null Phi = 0.1169, p-value = 0 #>  #> Empirical eigenvalue #1 = 3.84712, Max null eigenvalue = 2.23241, p-value = 0 #> Empirical eigenvalue #2 = 1.52017, Max null eigenvalue = 1.71318, p-value = 0.11 #> Empirical eigenvalue #3 = 0.70634, Max null eigenvalue = 1.3766, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #4 = 0.41356, Max null eigenvalue = 1.14496, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #5 = 0.34001, Max null eigenvalue = 0.93756, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #6 = 0.14515, Max null eigenvalue = 0.7892, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #7 = 0.02765, Max null eigenvalue = 0.62112, p-value = 1 #>  #> PC 1 is significant and accounts for 55% (95%-CI:39.3-65.1) of the total variation #>  #> Variables 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 7 have significant loadings on PC 1

what: Testing which variables have significant correlations
title: PCAtest: Statistical significance of PCA
text: Instead index loadings, can choose use variable correlations evaluate contributions significant PC axis:
code: data("ants") result<-PCAtest(ants, 100, 100, 0.05, indload=FALSE, varcorr=TRUE, counter=FALSE, plot=FALSE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 7 variables, 29 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 10.9186, Max null Psi = 2.7018, Min null Psi = 0.5938, p-value = 0 #> Empirical Phi = 0.5099, Max null Phi = 0.2536, Min null Phi = 0.1189, p-value = 0 #>  #> Empirical eigenvalue #1 = 3.84712, Max null eigenvalue = 2.16286, p-value = 0 #> Empirical eigenvalue #2 = 1.52017, Max null eigenvalue = 1.6875, p-value = 0.23 #> Empirical eigenvalue #3 = 0.70634, Max null eigenvalue = 1.44721, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #4 = 0.41356, Max null eigenvalue = 1.12624, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #5 = 0.34001, Max null eigenvalue = 0.94865, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #6 = 0.14515, Max null eigenvalue = 0.75295, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #7 = 0.02765, Max null eigenvalue = 0.64223, p-value = 1 #>  #> PC 1 is significant and accounts for 55% (95%-CI:44.7-66.3) of the total variation #>  #> Variables 2, and 3 have significant correlations with PC 1

title: Authors and Citation
text: Arley Camargo. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Camargo (2024). PCAtest: Statistical significance PCA. R package version 0.0.2, https://arleyc.github.io/PCAtest/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {PCAtest: Statistical significance of PCA},   author = {Arley Camargo},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.2},   url = {https://arleyc.github.io/PCAtest/}, }

title: Statistical significance of PCA
text: goal PCAtest evaluate overall significance PCA, PC axis, contributions observed variable significant axes based permutation-based statistical tests. PCAtest uses random permutations build null distributions several statistics PCAanalysis: Psi (Vieira 2012),Phi (Gleason Staelin 1975), rank--roots (ter Braak 1988), index loadings (Vieira 2012), correlations PC variables (Jackson 1991). Comparing distributions observed values statistics, function tests: (1) hypothesis correlational structure among observed variables expected random chance, (2) statistical significance PC, (3) contribution observed variable significant PC. function also calculates sampling variance around mean observed statistics based bootstrap replicates.

title: Statistical significance of PCA
text: can install released (version 0.02) development versions [GitHub] (https://github.com/) :

title: Statistical significance of PCA
code: library(PCAtest) # PCA analysis of five uncorrelated (r=0) variables library(MASS) mu <- rep(0,5) Sigma <- matrix(c(rep(c(1,0,0,0,0,0),4),1),5) ex0 <- mvrnorm(100, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma ) result<-PCAtest(ex0, 100, 100, 0.05, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 5 variables, 100 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 0.0906, Max null Psi = 0.5364, Min null Psi = 0.0391, p-value = 0.95 #> Empirical Phi = 0.0673, Max null Phi = 0.1638, Min null Phi = 0.0442, p-value = 0.95 #>  #> PCA is not significant! #PCA analysis of five correlated (r=0.25) variables Sigma <- matrix(c(rep(c(1,0.25,0.25,0.25,0.25,0.25),4),1),5) ex025 <- mvrnorm(100, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma ) result<-PCAtest(ex025, 100, 100, 0.05, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 5 variables, 100 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 1.4947, Max null Psi = 0.4902, Min null Psi = 0.0617, p-value = 0 #> Empirical Phi = 0.2734, Max null Phi = 0.1566, Min null Phi = 0.0555, p-value = 0 #>  #> Empirical eigenvalue #1 = 2.05104, Max null eigenvalue = 1.49457, p-value = 0 #> Empirical eigenvalue #2 = 0.95665, Max null eigenvalue = 1.23612, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #3 = 0.78234, Max null eigenvalue = 1.10792, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #4 = 0.72472, Max null eigenvalue = 0.97997, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #5 = 0.48526, Max null eigenvalue = 0.87503, p-value = 1 #>  #> PC 1 is significant and accounts for 41% (95%-CI:34.5-47.9) of the total variation #>  #> Variables 2, 3, and 4 have significant loadings on PC 1 #PCA analysis of five correlated (r=0.5) variables Sigma <- matrix(c(rep(c(1,0.5,0.5,0.5,0.5,0.5),4),1),5) ex05 <- mvrnorm(100, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma ) result<-PCAtest(ex05, 100, 100, 0.05, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 5 variables, 100 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 4.8505, Max null Psi = 0.6045, Min null Psi = 0.0382, p-value = 0 #> Empirical Phi = 0.4925, Max null Phi = 0.1739, Min null Phi = 0.0437, p-value = 0 #>  #> Empirical eigenvalue #1 = 2.9652, Max null eigenvalue = 1.59307, p-value = 0 #> Empirical eigenvalue #2 = 0.62114, Max null eigenvalue = 1.25937, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #3 = 0.53125, Max null eigenvalue = 1.09766, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #4 = 0.46017, Max null eigenvalue = 0.97471, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #5 = 0.42223, Max null eigenvalue = 0.88145, p-value = 1 #>  #> PC 1 is significant and accounts for 59.3% (95%-CI:51.1-67.2) of the total variation #>  #> Variables 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 have significant loadings on PC 1 #PCA analysis of seven morphological variables from 29 ant species (from # Wong and Carmona 2021,  https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.13568) data("ants") result<-PCAtest(ants, 100, 100, 0.05, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... title: Statistical significance of PCA
text: Camargo, . (2022) PCAtest: Testing statistical significance Principal Component Analysis R. PeerJ 10: e12967. doi: 10.7717/peerj.12967

what: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
title: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
text: PCAtest uses random permutations build null distributions several statistics PCA analysis: Psi (Vieira 2012), Phi (Gleason Staelin 1975), rank--roots (ter Braak 1988), index loadings (Vieira 2012), correlations PC variables (Jackson 1991). Comparing distributions observed values statistics, function tests: (1) hypothesis correlational structure among observed variables expected random chance, (2) statistical significance PC, (3) contribution observed variable significant PC. function also calculates sampling variance around mean observed statistics based bootstrap replicates.

title: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
code: PCAtest(   x,   nperm = 1000,   nboot = 1000,   alpha = 0.05,   indload = TRUE,   varcorr = FALSE,   counter = TRUE,   plot = TRUE )

title: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
text: x matrix dataframe variables columns observations rows. nperm Number random permutations build null distributions statistics. nboot Number bootstrap replicates build 95%-confidence intervals observed statistics. alpha Nominal alpha level statistical tests. indload logical indicating whether calculate index loadings variables significant PCs. varcorr logical indicating whether calculate correlations variables significant PCs. counter logical specifying whether show progress random sampling (bootstrap permutations) screen. plot logical specifying whether plot null distributions, observed statistics, 95%-confidence intervals statistics based random permutation bootstrap resampling.

title: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
text: object class “list” following elements: psiobs observed Psi statistic. phiobs observed Phi statistic. psi null distribution Psi values. phi null distribution Phi values. pervarobs percentage variance explained PC based observed data. pervarboot percentage variance explained PC based bootstrapped data. pervarbootci Confidence intervals percentage variance explained PC based bootstrapped data. pervarperm percentage variance explained PC based randomized data. pervarpermci Confidence intervals percentage variance explained PC based randomized data. indexloadobs index loadings observed data. indexloadboot index loadings bootstrapped data. indexloadbootci Confidence intervals index loadings based bootstrapped data. indexloadperm index loadings based randomized data. indexloadpermci Confidence intervals index loadings based randomized data. corobs varcorr=TRUE, correlations observed variables significant PC. corboot varcorr=TRUE, correlations observed variables significant PC based bootstrapped data. corbootci varcorr=TRUE, confidence intervals correlations variables significant PC based bootstrapped data. corperm varcorr=TRUE, correlations observed variables significant PC based randomized data. corpermci varcorr=TRUE, confidence intervals correlations variables significant PC based randomized data.

title: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
text: PCAtest uses function stats::prcomp run PCA using arguments scale = TRUE center = TRUE. PCAtest plots four types graphs single page: (1) histogram showing null distribution observed value Psi statistic, (2) histogram showing null distribution observed value Phi statistic, (3) bar plot percentage explained variance PC1, PC2, ..., etc., showing sampling variance based bootstrap replicates random permutations 95%-confidence intervals, (4) bar plot index loadings observed variable PC1, showing sampling variance bootstrap replicates random permutations 95%- confidence intervals. one PC significant, additional plots index loadings shown many new pages necessary given number significant PCs. PCA significant, based Psi Phi testing results, histograms (1) (2) shown.

title: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
text: Gleason, T. C. Staelin R. (1975) proposal handling missing data. Psychometrika, 40, 229–252. Jackson, J. E. (1991) User’s Guide Principal Components. John Wiley & Sons, New York, USA. title: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
text: Arley Camargo

title: PCAtest: Statistical Significance of PCA — PCAtest
code: #PCA analysis of five uncorrelated (r=0) variables library(MASS) mu <- rep(0,5) Sigma <- matrix(c(rep(c(1,0,0,0,0,0),4),1),5) ex0 <- mvrnorm(100, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma ) result<-PCAtest(ex0, 100, 100, 0.05, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 5 variables, 100 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 0.2505, Max null Psi = 0.4141, Min null Psi = 0.0363, p-value = 0.15 #> Empirical Phi = 0.1119, Max null Phi = 0.1439, Min null Phi = 0.0426, p-value = 0.15 #>  #> PCA is not significant!  #PCA analysis of five correlated (r=0.25) variables Sigma <- matrix(c(rep(c(1,0.25,0.25,0.25,0.25,0.25),4),1),5) ex025 <- mvrnorm(100, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma ) result<-PCAtest(ex025, 100, 100, 0.05, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE)  #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 5 variables, 100 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 2.1917, Max null Psi = 0.4513, Min null Psi = 0.0413, p-value = 0 #> Empirical Phi = 0.3310, Max null Phi = 0.1502, Min null Phi = 0.0454, p-value = 0 #>  #> Empirical eigenvalue #1 = 2.30607, Max null eigenvalue = 1.4752, p-value = 0 #> Empirical eigenvalue #2 = 0.84801, Max null eigenvalue = 1.2983, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #3 = 0.71629, Max null eigenvalue = 1.12184, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #4 = 0.60657, Max null eigenvalue = 0.97008, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #5 = 0.52305, Max null eigenvalue = 0.9082, p-value = 0.99 #>  #> PC 1 is significant and accounts for 46.1% (95%-CI:38.6-53) of the total variation #>  #> Variables 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 have significant loadings on PC 1 #>    #PCA analysis of five correlated (r=0.5) variables Sigma <- matrix(c(rep(c(1,0.5,0.5,0.5,0.5,0.5),4),1),5) ex05 <- mvrnorm(100, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma ) result<-PCAtest(ex05, 100, 100, 0.05, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 5 variables, 100 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 4.8917, Max null Psi = 0.5080, Min null Psi = 0.0431, p-value = 0 #> Empirical Phi = 0.4946, Max null Phi = 0.1594, Min null Phi = 0.0464, p-value = 0 #>  #> Empirical eigenvalue #1 = 2.97094, Max null eigenvalue = 1.5192, p-value = 0 #> Empirical eigenvalue #2 = 0.64342, Max null eigenvalue = 1.26189, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #3 = 0.54736, Max null eigenvalue = 1.10163, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #4 = 0.43055, Max null eigenvalue = 0.97966, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #5 = 0.40773, Max null eigenvalue = 0.86767, p-value = 1 #>  #> PC 1 is significant and accounts for 59.4% (95%-CI:51.8-68) of the total variation #>  #> Variables 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 have significant loadings on PC 1 #>    #PCA analysis of seven morphological variables from 29 ant species (from #Wong and Carmona 2021, https://doi.org/10.1111/2041-210X.13568) data("ants") result<-PCAtest(ants, 100, 100, 0.05, varcorr=FALSE, counter=FALSE, plot=TRUE) #>  #> Sampling bootstrap replicates... Please wait #>  #> Calculating confidence intervals of empirical statistics... Please wait #>  #> Sampling random permutations... Please wait #>  #> Comparing empirical statistics with their null distributions... Please wait #>  #> ======================================================== #> Test of PCA significance: 7 variables, 29 observations #> 100 bootstrap replicates, 100 random permutations #> ======================================================== #>  #> Empirical Psi = 10.9186, Max null Psi = 3.0303, Min null Psi = 0.6274, p-value = 0 #> Empirical Phi = 0.5099, Max null Phi = 0.2686, Min null Phi = 0.1222, p-value = 0 #>  #> Empirical eigenvalue #1 = 3.84712, Max null eigenvalue = 2.33045, p-value = 0 #> Empirical eigenvalue #2 = 1.52017, Max null eigenvalue = 1.63299, p-value = 0.25 #> Empirical eigenvalue #3 = 0.70634, Max null eigenvalue = 1.4709, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #4 = 0.41356, Max null eigenvalue = 1.10378, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #5 = 0.34001, Max null eigenvalue = 0.91727, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #6 = 0.14515, Max null eigenvalue = 0.77857, p-value = 1 #> Empirical eigenvalue #7 = 0.02765, Max null eigenvalue = 0.55742, p-value = 1 #>  #> PC 1 is significant and accounts for 55% (95%-CI:43.3-65.5) of the total variation #>  #> Variables 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 7 have significant loadings on PC 1 #>
